description: From Middle English market, from late Old English market (“market”) and Anglo-Norman markiet (Old French marchié); both ultimately from Latin mercātus (“trade, market”), from mercor (“I trade, deal in, buy”), itself derived from merx (“wares, merchandise”).

entries.meaning: A gathering of people for the purchase and sale of merchandise at a set time, often periodic.
examples: The right to hold a weekly market was an invaluable privilege not given to all towns in the Middle Ages.

entries.meaning: City square or other fairly spacious site where traders set up stalls and buyers browse the merchandise.

examples: Stop by the market on your way home and pick up some milk

entries.meaning: A group of potential customers for one's product.
examples: We believe that the market for the new widget is the older homeowner.

entries.meaning: A geographical area where a certain commercial demand exists.
examples: Foreign markets were lost as our currency rose versus their valuta.

entries.meaning: A formally organized, sometimes monopolistic, system of trading in specified goods or effects.
examples: The stock market ceased to be monopolized by the paper-shuffling national stock exchanges with the advent of Internet markets.

entries.meaning: The sum total traded in a process of individuals trading for certain commodities.
(obsolete) The price for which a thing is sold in a market; hence, value; worth.

verbs.description: market (third-person singular simple present markets, present participle marketing, simple past and past participle marketed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (products or services) available for sale and promote them.
examples: We plan to market an ecology model by next quarter.
We marketed more this quarter already than all last year!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To deal in a market; to buy or sell; to make bargains for provisions or goods.
(intransitive) To shop in a market; to attend a market.
